page.title: 05THURLASTON CHANGING
page.content: 1849-Thurlaston church built,cost $1000 1900-The Plough public house closed by the Duke,now named Stocks House. 1910-Miller changed from sails to steam Local smith charged $1 to shoe a horse. 1913-Rugby Advertiser mentioned pig weighing 35 stone from Biggin Hall farm 1917-Duke of Buccleuch sold Thurlaston. Flour still being carted to Coventry. 1924-Sails on windmill taken down. 1928-Smithy closed down. 1920's-Horse and cart changed to motor. 1931-Electricity introduced. 1939-Mains water,public wells condemned 1948-Two army huts became village hall. 1952-7 street lights installed. Public telephone in Post Office. 1953-Coronation celebrated. 1977-Jubilee street parties. 1978-Gales blew down Elm tree in Biggin Hall lane where villagers had drunk beer.
